moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. a3 Bxc3:
The Knight is blockading the bisshop from c4.
Best now was Bc1, because after whites next move the Bisshop is remains inactive at the side
With the intend of freeing his own a pawn, which will have gain a free road to a1
moves.25. Qg3 c4: An there it is: Whites bisshop is permanently sidetracked, while the KNight gains a great position at d3
moves.26. exd5 Rxd5: Another piece comes to join in
moves.27. Rfe1 Nd3 28. Rcb1 Rg5:
In just a few moves white position has deteriorated fast.
After a futute Bc6, whites King should feel very uncomfortable.

Of course Black has no intention of trading his Knight against a white rook.
The Knight in this position is stringer then a rook!
moves.29. Qe3:
Now Re5 wins a rook and the game.
However the position on the Kings side it just too tempting, and black decides to go for having some fun, and hunting for bigger game
moves.29... Bc6 30. Ref1 Rg4:
Wining the Knight.

The outcome is better then it would have been after 29.Re5, since most of blacks pieces are aming for whites King.
moves.31. Nf3 Bxf3:
The attack on whites Kings is simply overwhelming. 

The white rook on b1 and the white Bisshop on a1 are out of action.
At the moment white is two practically pieces ahead.
moves.32. g3:
Weakens whites King position further.
Checkmate is not far away
moves.32... Re4: Prearing the way for the Knight to go to f4
moves.34... Ne2+ 35. Kh2 Qxh4+:
The Queens sacrifice is a simple one, but a nice ending for a good game.
Of course hxg4, Rxg4 is checkmate, using all pioeces white has available, except the rook on a8.
The simply Rxh4 would have been just as effective, but I just liked the idea of sacrificing my Qeeun.
